entry.title: Week 42, 2025: Discussion continued on tuple projections RFC with focus on row-polymorphic tuples
entry.content:
Summary

Ongoing design discussion on tuple projections RFC focusing on row-polymorphic tuples approach

Activity

  • Tuple projections RFC (#57) by Alistair proposes adding labeled and unlabeled tuple projections with syntax like x.tuple and x.3 for accessing tuple elements, with ongoing discussion about row-polymorphic tuples as a potential typing approach
entry.summary: Discussion continued on tuple projections RFC with focus on row-polymorphic tuples

entry.title: Week 41, 2025: One RFC proposal withdrawn following community feedback on syntactic sugar design tradeoffs
entry.content:
Summary

Discussion and closure of for-in syntax proposal, ongoing tuple projections RFC review

Activity

  • Sacha Ayoun withdrew the for...in syntax RFC proposal following community feedback about syntactic sugar design tradeoffs and OCaml's functional programming idioms (#56)
  • Ongoing tuple projections RFC by Alistair proposing labeled and unlabeled tuple field access syntax like x.tuple and x.3 (#57)
entry.summary: One RFC proposal withdrawn following community feedback on syntactic sugar design tradeoffs

entry.title: Week 40, 2025: Ongoing discussion of tuple projection RFC with feedback on row-polymorphic tuples and labeled projection semantics
entry.content:
Summary

Continued discussion on tuple projections RFC addressing row-polymorphic tuples and labeled vs unlabeled projection behavior

Activity

  • Ongoing discussion on tuple projections RFC by Alistair (#57) proposing labeled and unlabeled tuple projections with syntax like x.tuple and x.3, with Samuel Vivien providing detailed feedback on row-polymorphic tuples expressiveness, pattern matching semantics consistency, and backend implementation considerations for polymorphism support
entry.summary: Ongoing discussion of tuple projection RFC with feedback on row-polymorphic tuples and labeled projection semantics

entry.title: Week 39, 2025: Two RFC proposals opened: tuple projections and for...in syntax enhancement
entry.content:
Summary

One new RFC opened for tuple projections, ongoing discussion on for...in syntax

Activity

  • New tuple projections RFC opened by Alistair proposing labeled and 0-indexed unlabeled tuple access syntax (#57)
  • Ongoing for...in syntax RFC discussion by Sacha Ayoun with community feedback from Yawar Amin and Daniel Bünzli regarding iteration syntax improvements (#56)
entry.summary: Two RFC proposals opened: tuple projections and for...in syntax enhancement

entry.title: Week 38, 2025: Active discussion on for...in loop proposal with detailed technical feedback from community members
entry.content:
Summary

One RFC proposal for for...in syntax remains open with technical discussions on implementation approaches

Activity

  • RFC proposal for for...in construct by Sacha Ayoun continues receiving detailed technical feedback from community members (#56)
  • Language design discussions focus on iteration mechanisms, performance implications, and compatibility with modular implicits including suggestions for alternative syntax approaches
entry.summary: Active discussion on for...in loop proposal with detailed technical feedback from community members

entry.title: Week 37, 2025: New `for...in` syntax RFC proposed and ongoing language committee governance discussions
entry.content:
Summary

New for...in syntax RFC opened with community discussions on language design and governance policy updates

Activity

  • New RFC opened by Sacha Ayoun proposing for...in syntax to improve readability and make OCaml more approachable for newcomers (#56), generating technical discussion with Frédéric Loyer, Kate, and Gaëtan Gilbert about existing iteration patterns and performance considerations
  • Language committee governance discussions continued on conflict of interest policy by Florian Angeletti (#55) with extensive feedback from Gabriel Scherer, Jeremy Yallop, and Guillaume Munch-Maccagnoni addressing transparency, decision-making processes, and community involvement
entry.summary: New `for...in` syntax RFC proposed and ongoing language committee governance discussions

entry.content:
Summary

Single PR opened addressing OCaml Language Committee governance with transparency policy for conflicts of interest

Activity

entry.summary: New PR opened proposing transparency-based policy for handling conflicts of interest in the OCaml Language Committee

entry.title: Week 27, 2025: RFC discussions progressed on transparent ascription and primitive aliases
entry.content:
Summary

Two ongoing RFC discussions received continued development input

Activity

  • Transparent ascription RFC discussion continued with Clément Blaudeau providing updates on aliasing restrictions for persistent modules only, referencing implementation work and bug reports (#54)
  • Primitive aliases RFC received feedback from Clément Blaudeau exploring potential extensions to signature constraint mechanisms for external primitives (#44)
entry.summary: RFC discussions progressed on transparent ascription and primitive aliases

Continued discussion on transparent ascription RFC with modular implicits integration benefits

Activity

  • Transparent ascription RFC discussion continued with Samuel Vivien highlighting benefits for modular implicits and module signature simplification in #54

Ongoing discussion on transparent ascription RFC addressing module system improvements and performance questions

entry.title: Week 16, 2025: Active RFC discussion on transparent ascription proposal with expert consensus to proceed to prototype implementation
entry.content:
Summary

RFC #54 on transparent ascription gained expert approval for prototype implementation phase

Activity

  • Transparent ascription RFC by Clément Blaudeau received detailed feedback and approval to proceed to prototype implementation from Gabriel Scherer, Leo White, and Xavier Leroy (#54)
  • RFC discussion included technical clarifications on static vs dynamic aliases, syntax considerations with underscore notation, and coordination with potential implicit resolution features by @samsam1 (#54)
  • Implementation approval given by Xavier Leroy after direct discussion with Clément Blaudeau, describing the proposal as "really well thought-out" (#54)
entry.summary: Active RFC discussion on transparent ascription proposal with expert consensus to proceed to prototype implementation

entry.title: Week 15, 2025: New RFC for transparent ascription and module aliasing redesign opened with extensive expert review
entry.content:
Summary

Major RFC proposal for transparent ascription and module aliasing redesign opened with detailed expert review

Activity

  • New RFC proposal for transparent ascription and module aliasing redesign opened by Clément Blaudeau with comprehensive 464-line specification covering syntax changes, backward compatibility, and implementation details (#54)
  • Expert review and discussion by Gabriel Scherer providing detailed technical feedback on backward compatibility considerations, syntax clarity, and semantic model questions with multiple rounds of clarifying comments (#54)
  • Technical validation by Leo White focusing on linking behavior of explicit static aliases and design decisions around -no-alias-deps flag transition strategy (#54)
  • Language design review by Xavier Leroy covering metavariable conventions, transparent ascription comparisons to Coq/Rocq, and suggestions for clearer documentation structure (#54)
entry.summary: New RFC for transparent ascription and module aliasing redesign opened with extensive expert review

entry.title: Week 14, 2025: RFC discussion continues on implicit source positions with design debates between multiple contributors
entry.content:
Summary

Ongoing RFC discussion about implicit source positions design with technical debate on API choices

Activity

  • Implicit source positions RFC discussion progressed with Olivier Nicole leading the proposal and receiving detailed feedback from Richard Eisenberg, Gabriel Scherer, and Daniel Bünzli on API design trade-offs (#52)
  • Technical design debate centered on whether to support multiple position types (Lexing.position vs Textloc.t) with considerations for Jane Street compatibility and performance optimization requirements (#52)
  • Implementation details discussed including GADT-based approach for multiple implicit argument types, space/time performance measurements, and migration path from existing Jane Street implementation (#52)
entry.summary: RFC discussion continues on implicit source positions with design debates between multiple contributors

entry.title: Week 13, 2025: New RFC proposed for Relocatable OCaml feature with dev meeting approval
entry.content:
Summary

Single RFC opened for Relocatable OCaml with consensus approval from dev meeting

Activity

  • Relocatable OCaml RFC opened by David Allsopp proposing compiler and Standard Library location flexibility (#53)
  • Dev meeting consensus achieved with Nicolás Ojeda Bär confirming RFC approval and transition to review stage (#53)
entry.summary: New RFC proposed for Relocatable OCaml feature with dev meeting approval

entry.title: Week 12, 2025: Technical discussion continued on implicit source positions RFC
entry.content:
Summary

Ongoing discussion on implicit source positions RFC with technical design debate

Activity

  • Technical design discussion continues on implicit source positions RFC (#52) with contributions from Olivier Nicole, Gabriel Scherer, Daniel Bünzli, and Stephen Dolan
entry.summary: Technical discussion continued on implicit source positions RFC

entry.title: Week 11, 2025: Technical discussion on implicit source positions RFC syntax and type handling for improved debugging capabilities
entry.content:
Summary

Detailed technical discussion on RFC #52 regarding syntax choices and implementation approaches for automatic call position tracking

Activity

  • Syntax consensus reached for implicit source positions feature with Richard Eisenberg summarizing agreement on ?loc:[%call_pos] in types, ?(loc = [%call_pos]) in function definitions, and optional ~(loc : [%call_pos]) at call sites (#52)
  • Data type debate between positions versus locations involving Daniel Bünzli advocating for [%call_loc] with full span information using existing __POS_OF__ format, and Ty Overby defending single position approach for performance and usability concerns (#52)
  • Performance considerations discussed by Simon Cruanes regarding allocation behavior and Ty Overby highlighting binary size impacts for jsofocaml programs (#52)
  • Format compatibility analysis by Gabriel Scherer and Daniel Bünzli comparing OCaml's error reporting format with proposed location representations and Unicode handling (#52)
entry.summary: Technical discussion on implicit source positions RFC syntax and type handling for improved debugging capabilities

entry.title: Week 10, 2025: Ongoing discussion on include functor RFC with updated signature explanation
entry.content:
Summary

Continued refinement of include functor RFC proposal with enhanced signature documentation

Activity

  • Chris Casinghino updated include functor RFC with expanded signature explanation incorporating feedback from Gabriel Scherer and Leo White (#43)
entry.summary: Ongoing discussion on include functor RFC with updated signature explanation

entry.title: Week 9, 2025: Ongoing design discussions for implicit source positions RFC with community feedback on syntax and semantics
entry.content: Activity report for ocaml/RFCs - Week 9, 2025
entry.summary: Ongoing design discussions for implicit source positions RFC with community feedback on syntax and semantics

entry.title: Week 8, 2025: New RFC proposal for implicit source positions and continued discussion on include functor feature
entry.content:
Summary

One new RFC opened proposing implicit source positions with continued discussion on include functor

Activity

  • Olivier Nicole opened implicit source positions RFC (#52) proposing a new arrow type syntax loc:[%call_pos] -> that automatically fills function parameters with call site positions, useful for monadic bind tracing and testing framework improvements
  • Ongoing technical discussion on the include functor RFC (#43) by Chris Casinghino with Florian Angeletti confirming language committee involvement and extensive debate about syntax alternatives involving Gabriel Scherer, François Pottier, and others
entry.summary: New RFC proposal for implicit source positions and continued discussion on include functor feature

entry.title: Week 7, 2025: OCaml Language Committee officially established with governance documentation merged
entry.content:
Summary

Language committee formation reached completion with community consensus and launch announcement

Activity

  • OCaml Language Committee officially launched after Richard Eisenberg merged comprehensive governance documentation (#51)
  • Community consensus achieved through extensive discussion involving David Allsopp, Nicolás Ojeda Bär, Florian Angeletti, and Josh Berdine on committee scope and procedures
  • Public announcement planned by Florian Angeletti across multiple channels including ocaml/ocaml, caml-list, and discuss forum to introduce the committee to the broader community
entry.summary: OCaml Language Committee officially established with governance documentation merged

entry.title: Week 6, 2025: OCaml Language Committee documentation proposal by Richard Eisenberg attracted community discussion
entry.content:
Summary

OCaml Language Committee governance proposal under discussion with community feedback

Activity

  • OCaml Language Committee governance documentation introduced by Richard Eisenberg to formalize consensus-building process for language proposals (#51)
entry.summary: OCaml Language Committee documentation proposal by Richard Eisenberg attracted community discussion

entry.title: Week 5, 2025: OCaml Language Committee documentation added to formalize consensus-building process for language proposals
entry.content:
Summary

Single PR opened and later merged establishing OCaml Language Committee governance structure

Activity

  • OCaml Language Committee governance structure introduced by Richard Eisenberg with comprehensive documentation covering committee composition, decision-making process, and community submission guidelines (#51)
entry.summary: OCaml Language Committee documentation added to formalize consensus-building process for language proposals

Discussion activity on atomic record fields RFC regarding inline records implementation challenges

Activity

entry.title: Week 49, 2024: Discussion activity on garbage collection proposal for minor heap optimization
entry.content:
Summary

Ongoing discussion on GC proposal for minor heap optimization with reference counting approach

Activity

  • Garbage collection optimization proposal by Christophe Raffalli continues discussion on minor heap reference counting approach to improve latency with larger heap sizes (#50)
  • Technical feedback provided by Stephen Dolan addressing terminology clarification and performance concerns regarding atomic operations in multi-domain contexts (#50)
entry.summary: Discussion activity on garbage collection proposal for minor heap optimization

entry.title: Week 48, 2024: Three new GC improvement proposals opened by Christophe Raffalli, with ongoing discussions on types as module arguments
entry.content:
Summary

Three new GC proposals opened plus continued refinement discussions on types as module arguments proposal

Activity

  • Three new GC proposal PRs opened by Christophe Raffalli exploring garbage collector improvements, though two were immediately closed due to technical issues and replaced (#48, #49, #50)
  • Types as module arguments proposal by Samuel Vivien continued with detailed technical discussions about value restriction and type escaping scope, with contributions from Gabriel Scherer and Didier Remy on implementation strategy (#40)
entry.summary: Three new GC improvement proposals opened by Christophe Raffalli, with ongoing discussions on types as module arguments

Ongoing technical discussion on atomic record fields design alternatives

Activity

  • Continued technical discussion on atomic record fields design with Gabriel Scherer, Vesa Karvonen, Leo White, and @clef-men exploring design tradeoffs between ('r, 'v) Field.t and 'v Loc.t approaches (#39)

entry.title: Week 44, 2024: Maintainer meeting discussions on mixed-atomicity memory model and unit headers for OCaml source files
entry.content:
Summary

Updates to two long-standing RFCs with maintainer meeting feedback and clarifications

Activity

  • Mixed-atomicity memory model RFC received maintainer meeting discussion by Gabriel Scherer with clarification from Stephen Dolan on relaxed reads behavior and next steps for implementation verification (#42)
  • Unit headers for OCaml source files RFC discussed at maintainer meeting by Gabriel Scherer with suggestions for syntax exploration and parsing considerations including extension point alternatives (#26)
entry.summary: Maintainer meeting discussions on mixed-atomicity memory model and unit headers for OCaml source files
